title: Sheet 4C
publication_title: James Ensor: The Temptation of Saint Anthony
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section body" id="body">This image was created with media similar to those used in sheet 4B and has likewise diminished over time. Details can be discerned with the aid of infrared reflectography (see fig. 1). The composition is a coherent whole. A hybrid cannon-animal, like those in Jacques Callot’s etching The Temptation of Saint Anthony, hovers above the scene (see fig. 2; see also sheet 3B). At center right, a creature resembling a warthog extends across to sheet 4D, as if intended to make a visual link, and flames extend from sheet 5C below. The sheet was visibly trimmed along its left edge. At center is a multitiered structure with colonnades, reminiscent of the building in Ensor’s print Capture of a Strange Town (fig. 3). Engulfed in flames and smoke, it appears to be under attack from an apocalyptic phalanx of fantastic flying creatures, one of which carries a tattered red-and-blue-striped flag (an allusion perhaps to the French flag). The building is also similar in its lower stories to the Gothic Brussels Town Hall (1402–20; see fig. 4), located on the Grand Place not far from the Academy of Fine Arts, where Ensor studied in the late 1870s. In 1830 the provisional government assembled at the Town Hall, provoking the separation of the Southern Provinces from the Netherlands and the formation of the modern Belgian state. The top of the structure in the drawing resembles the tiered dome of the Palace of Justice designed by Joseph Poelaert and inaugurated on October 15, 1883 (see fig. 5). SMC/KJN

The action in sheets 3A, 3B, 3C, 3A, 4B, and 4C is the source of the engraving Devils Thrashing Angels and Archangels (fig. 6). It also indirectly inspired other etchings, such as The Terrible Archer (fig. 7), Cataclysms (fig. 8), Wizards in a Squall (fig. 9), and The Elephant’s Joke (fig. 10). Although Devils Thrashing Angels and Archangels is not a direct reproduction of these sheets, the chaotic composition and frightful elements are similar to Saint Anthony’s torments. Many motifs appear in both the print and the drawing, for example, the hot-air balloon, train, sawfish, headless bodies, octopi, insects, elephant, and submarine.

In the drawing the chaos is somewhat contained by the use of schematic registers, but in the etching Ensor dispensed with the organizational structure and allowed the chaos to become overwhelming. Sources of inspiration for the chaos include The Fall of the Rebel Angels by Pieter Bruegel I (fig. 11); versions of the temptation after Pieter Bruegel (fig. 12), by Martin Schongauer (fig. 13), and by Jacques Callot (fig. 14); and battle scenes by the Japanese artists Utagawa Kuniyoshi and Utagawa Kunisada (fig. 15 and fig. 16). These artists provided ideas about overlapping, clashing compositions that Ensor assimilated into his own work. He interpreted these sources to offer viewers a distilled representation that condenses the energy, imagination, anxiety, and virulence of its predecessors. Thanks to this synthesis, the image possesses its own logic and magic that captivates even as it amuses and overwhelms viewers with its detail. ST

fig. 1 Infrared and natural-light images of sheet 4C of Ensor’s Temptation of Saint Anthony (1887–88). The Art Institute of Chicago, 2006.87.

fig. 2 Jacques Callot (French, 1592–1635). The Temptation of Saint Anthony (detail), 1635. Etching in black on ivory laid paper; image/sheet (trimmed to platemark): 35.6 × 46.6 cm (14 × 18 3/8 in.). The Art Institute of Chicago, Print and Drawing Special Account, 1938.1250. This detail shows the foreground figure that likely inspired the cannon/animal hybrid in Ensor’s drawing.

fig. 3 James Ensor (Belgian, 1860–1949). Capture of a Strange Town, 1888. Etching on paper; image: 17.2 × 23.2 cm (6 3/4 × 9 1/8 in.); plate: 17.9 × 23.8 cm (7 1/16 × 9 3/8 in.); sheet: 35.6 × 47.9 cm (14 × 18 7/8 in.). The Museum of Modern Art, New York, Purchase, 115.1949. Digital image © The Museum of Modern Art/Licensed by SCALA/Art Resource, NY.

fig. 4 Brussels Town Hall, c. 1880.

fig. 5 Palace of Justice, Brussels, 20th century.

fig. 6 James Ensor (Belgian, 1860–1949). Devils Thrashing Angels and Archangels, 1888. Etching from a copper plate, in black with hand-coloring, on buff laid paper; image: 24.8 × 28.7 cm (9 3/4 × 11 5/16 in.); plate: 26.3 × 30.7 cm (10 3/8 × 12 1/8 in.); sheet: 33.3 × 50.8 cm (13 1/8 × 20 in.). The Art Institute of Chicago, Olivia Shaler Swan Fund Income, 1971.629.

fig. 7 James Ensor (Belgian, 1860–1949). The Terrible Archer, 1888. Etching from a zinc plate, in black, on cream wove paper; image/plate: 17.7 × 23.9 cm (7 × 9 3/8 in.); sheet: 28.3 × 39.5 cm (11 1/8 × 15 9/16 in.). The Art Institute of Chicago, Print and Drawing Club Fund, 1946.1042.

fig. 8 James Ensor (Belgian, 1860–1949). Cataclysms, 1888. Etching from a zinc plate, in black, on cream wove paper; image: 17.5 × 23.5 cm (6 7/8 × 9 1/4 in.); plate: 17.9 × 23.8 cm (7 1/16 × 9 3/8 in.); sheet: 34 × 47.2 cm (13 3/8 × 18 5/8 in.). The Art Institute of Chicago, Joseph Brooks Fair Fund, 1943.1020.

fig. 9 James Ensor (Belgian, 1860–1949). Wizards in a Squall, 1888. Etching from a zinc plate, in black, on cream wove paper; image/plate: 17.9 × 23.6 cm (7 1/16 × 9 5/16 in.); sheet: 28.6 × 39.9 cm (11 1/4 × 15 3/4 in.). The Art Institute of Chicago, Print and Drawing Club Collection, 1946.264.

fig. 10 James Ensor (Belgian, 1860–1949). The Elephant’s Joke, 1888. Etching on paper; 17.9 × 23.8 cm (7 1/16 × 9 3/8 in.). Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco, Gift of A. Justin and Lynn M. Sterling, 2005.171.4. © Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco.

fig. 11 Pieter Bruegel I (Flemish, c. 1525–1569). The Fall of the Rebel Angels, 1562. Oil on panel; 117 × 162 cm (46 × 64 in.). Royal Museums of Fine Arts of Belgium, Brussels, 584. © Royal Museums of Fine Arts of Belgium, Brussels/photograph: J. Geleyns/Ro scan.

fig. 12 Pieter van der Heyden (Flemish, c. 1530–after 1572) after Pieter Bruegel I (Flemish, c. 1525–1569). The Temptation of Saint Anthony, 1556. Engraving on laid paper; 24.3 × 32.5 cm (9 9/16 × 12 13/16 in.). The Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute, 2001.13.3. Image © Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute, Williamstown, Massachusetts, USA (photograph by Michael Agee).

fig. 13 Martin Schongauer (German, c. 1450–1491). The Temptation of Saint Anthony, 1470–75. Engraving in black on cream laid paper; sheet: 32 × 23.5 cm (12 5/16 × 9 1/16 in.). The Art Institute of Chicago, Gift of Mrs. Potter Palmer, Jr., 1955.1227.

fig. 14 Jacques Callot (French, 1592–1635). The Temptation of Saint Anthony, 1635. Etching in black on ivory laid paper; image/sheet (trimmed to platemark): 35.6 × 46.6 cm (14 × 18 3/8 in.). The Art Institute of Chicago, Print and Drawing Special Account, 1938.1250.

fig. 15 Utagawa Kuniyoshi (Japanese, 1797–1861). Published by Kogaya Katsugorō (Japanese, c. 1843–1874). The Battle of Dan-no-ura: Suke no Tsubone, Shinchūnagon Taira Tomomori, and Sagami Gorō, c. 1844. Woodblock print (nishiki-e); ink and color on paper; vertical ōban triptych; 36.7 × 75.3 cm (14 7/16 × 29 5/8 in.). Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, William Sturgis Bigelow Collection, 11.27029-31. Photograph © 2014 Museum of Fine Arts, Boston.

fig. 16 Utagawa Kunisada (Japanese, 1786–1864). Published by Kawaguchiya Uhei (Japanese, c. 1800–1852). The Killing of Ten (Jūban kiri): Soga Gorō Tokimune and Gosho no Gorōmaru Shigemune, c. 1820. Woodblock print (nishiki-e); ink and color on paper; vertical ōban; 39 × 25.5 cm (15 3/8 × 10 1/16 in.). Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, William Sturgis Bigelow Collection, 11.21579. Photograph © 2014 Museum of Fine Arts, Boston.
